options.label: Mixed Housing Suburban
options.option:
Under the proposed zone – Plan Change 78, the property has a zoning of Residential – Mixed Housing Suburban.  This zone is to be the most widespread residential zone in Auckland.  Its density controls allow a moderate level of intensification, while retaining a relatively spacious quality consistent with a suburban residential character, compared to the Mixed Housing Urban and Terrace Housing and Apartment Buildings zones.  
Subdivision and development within the zone allows two dwellings per site as a permitted activity and three or more dwellings being a restricted discretionary activity.  Further, development of two dwellings will need to comply with the following standards within the Mixed Housing Suburban zone:
Building Height
Height in relation to boundary
Minimum yard depth setbacks from each boundary
Maximum impervious area
Building coverage
Landscaped area
Outlook space
Daylight ingress
Outdoor living space
Fencing and wall restrictions
Subdivision for three or more dwellings within this zone, while being restricted discretionary will also need to comply with the following standards within the zone, building height; height in relation to boundary and minimum yard depth setbacks from each boundary. 
Vacant proposed site subdivision is a restricted discretionary activity within this zone and allows a net site area of 400 sm for parent sites that are less than one hectare.  For parent sites that are in excess of one hectare, vacant proposed site subdivision is a discretionary activity with the following rules regarding site areas:
Minimum net site area	320 sm
Minimum average net site area	400 sm
Maximum average net site area	480 sm
The Mixed Housing Suburban zone aims to enable a variety of housing types and encourage development as it is the most wide-spread residential zone under the unitary plan.  The zone is concentrated around residential use but allows for non – residential activities that will support the social and economic well-being of the community while monitoring any effects on the residential amenity of the zone.

options.label: Mixed Housing Urban
options.option:
Under the proposed zone – Plan Change 78, the property has a zoning of Residential – Mixed Housing Urban.  This zone is generally located between the Mixed Housing Suburban and the Terrace Housing and Apartment Buildings zones, providing a transition in density between these two zones and allowing three storey dwellings in locations close to the service network.  The zone provides for housing in a variety of sizes and forms, including detached dwellings, terrace housing and low-rise apartments.  
Subdivision and development within the zone allows two dwellings per site as a permitted activity and three or more dwellings being a restricted discretionary activity.  Further, development of two dwellings will need to comply with the following standards within the Mixed Housing Urban zone:
Building Height
Height in relation to boundary
Minimum yard depth setbacks from each boundary
Maximum impervious area
Building coverage
Landscaped area
Outlook space
Daylight ingress
Outdoor living space
Fencing and wall restrictions
Subdivision of three or more dwellings within this zone, while being restricted discretionary, will also need to comply with the following standards within the zone, building height; height in relation to boundary and minimum yard depth setbacks from each boundary. 
Vacant proposed site subdivision is a restricted discretionary activity within this zone and allows a net site area of 300 sm for parent sites that are less than one hectare.  For parent sites that are in excess of one hectare, vacant proposed site subdivision is a discretionary activity with the following rules regarding site areas:
Minimum net site area	240 sm
Minimum average net site area	300 sm
Maximum average net site area	360 sm
The Mixed Housing Urban zone will allow more intense subdivision in comparison to the Mixed Housing Suburban zone, with land near the Business – Metropolitan Centre zone and the Business – Town Centre zone, high – density residential areas and close to the public transport network is used efficiently for high density residential living.  Subdivision will predominantly comprise of three-storey buildings in a variety of forms but still maintain an urban built character within the zone while providing quality residential amenity.  Any non – residential activity will support the social, economic and cultural well-being while being compatible with the scale and intensity of development anticipated by the zone.

options.label: Terrace Housing and Apartment Buildings
options.option:
Under the proposed zone – Plan Change 78, the property has a zoning of Residential – Terrace Housing and Apartment Buildings.  This zone is a high intensity zone enabling a greater intensity of development providing for urban residential living in the form of terrace housing and apartments.  This zone is predominantly located around metropolitan, town and local centres and the public transport network to support the highest levels of intensification.  
Due to the intensification that can be achieved within this zone, dwellings are a restricted discretionary activity with building coverage not exceeding 50% of the net site area.  The following standards must be complied with when constructing dwellings within this zone:
Building Height 
Height in relation to boundary 
Minimum yard depth setbacks from each boundary
Maximum impervious area
Fencing and wall restrictions
Vacant proposed site subdivision is a restricted discretionary activity within this zone and allows a net site area of 1,200 sm for parent sites that are less than one hectare. 
The Terrace Housing and Apartment Buildings zone aims to keep land near public transport networks efficient with their use and to be of a high-density.  Development focuses on high, predominantly five, six or seven storey buildings in identified areas, in a variety of forms.  Non-residential activities provide for the community’s social, economic and cultural well-being so as to contribute to the amenity of the neighbourhood.

options.label: Large Lot
options.option:
Under the Auckland Unitary Plan (Operative in Part), the property has a zoning of Large Lot.  This zone is generally located to the periphery of urban areas where development is keeping within the areas spacious landscape character, qualities and natural features. 
Subdivision and development within the zone allows one dwelling per site as a permitted activity and more than one dwelling being a discretionary activity.  Further, building coverage must not exceed 20% of the net site area or 400 sm, whichever is the lesser of the two.  One dwelling per site must comply with the following standards:
Building Height
Minimum yard depth setbacks from each boundary
Maximum impervious area
Development within the Large Lot zone will be limited, as permitted activities, to demolition of buildings, internal and external alterations to buildings, accessory buildings (to the main building) and additions to an existing dwelling.
Vacant proposed site subdivision is a restricted discretionary activity within this zone and allows a net site area of 4,000 sm for parent sites that are less than one hectare. We have estimated, based upon the density of the balance development land, that 4 lots of circa 790 sm each would be achievable.
The Large Lot zone aims to restrict intense residential development and maintain an emphasis on the landscape qualities and spacious landscape character.  Site sizes will be large as well as being able to accommodate on-site wastewater treatment and disposal.  Non-residential activities will support the social and economic well-being of the community and are compatible with the scale and intensity of development anticipated within the zone while monitoring any effects on the residential amenity of the zone.

options.label: Single House
options.option:
Under the Auckland Unitary Plan (Operative in Part), the property has a zoning of Residential – Single House.  This zones purpose is to maintain and enhance the amenity values of established residential neighbourhoods.  Multi-unit development is not anticipated within this zone, with the zone also applicable to some Greenfield developments.
Subdivision and development within the zone allows one dwelling per site and the conversion of a principal dwelling into a maximum of two dwellings as permitted activities.  Further, building coverage must not exceed 35% of the net site area.  One dwelling per site must comply with the following standards within the Single House zone:
Building Height
Height in relation to boundary
Minimum yard depth setbacks from each boundary
Maximum impervious area
Fencing and wall restrictions
Vacant proposed site subdivision is a restricted discretionary activity within this zone and allows a net site area of 600 sm for parent sites that are less than one hectare.  For parent sites that are in excess of one hectare, vacant proposed site subdivision is a discretionary activity with the following rules regarding site areas:
Minimum net site area		480 sm
Minimum average net site area		600 sm
Maximum average net site area		720 sm
The Single House zone aims to keep within the amenity values and is characterised by one or two storey high buildings consistent with a suburban built character.  Development focuses on amenity of established residential neighbourhoods including those based on special character informed by the past, spacious sites with some large trees, a coastal setting or other factors such as established neighbourhood character.  Non - residential activities provide for the community’s social, economic and cultural well-being so as to contribute to the amenity of the neighbourhood.
